post_text: September is National Suicide Prevention Month. Suicidal thoughts can affect people of all ages, genders, ethnicities, and other backgrounds. According to the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, 48,344 people died by suicide in 2018. It is important to have honest discussions about this serious topic so people become aware of the signs and are comfortable speaking about it. Throughout the month of September, we will be sharing posts related to suicide with hopes that it will foster conversation and awareness. If you have any concerns that your child has suicidal thoughts, please IMMEDIATELY call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.

post_text: September 30 is the deadline to complete the 2020 Census. Although the deadline was extended due to the COVID-19 pandemic, many households still have not submitted their surveys and this lack of participation will have a detrimental impact on schools for years to come. The census has significant implications for public schools. The data will help determine how billions of federal education dollars are distributed, since funding formulas rely heavily on population and poverty levels. Don’t don’t let this opportunity for everyone to be counted pass us by! Fill out your census form today at 2020census.gov.

If you have any questions, please contact your main office.

In closing, please continue to be safe. Each individual plays an important role in preventing the spread of this illness.

post_text: Weeks before the Statewide school closure and long before the term “social distancing” had become commonplace, students at Ellenville Elementary School were treated to an inspiring visit by children’s book author and Ellenville alum Nakeyia Jones. Jones, who has vitiligo, wrote a book called “Super Spots.” In it, a young girl named Nia has the rare skin condition, which she explains to her classmates in a positive and fun way. Jones told the Ellenville students that she wrote the book to help raise awareness about her condition and to teach children to accept and appreciate each other’s differences. “I want kids to understand that we may not all look the same, but we all deserve to be treated with respect,” she said.

Together, we are facing an unprecedented health crisis in our community, which is rapidly evolving. We will provide more information in the next few days regarding availability of student meals (breakfast and lunch) and learning activities.

While there is an executive order from the Governor about the waiver of the 180 school day requirement, school districts must first use all available emergency closing days and vacation days before a waiver will be granted. Currently, we will be closed for 10 school days as a result of the mandated closing. Due to a very mild winter, there are currently 7 emergency closing days that will be used for the closing over the next two weeks. In addition, 3 days of the Spring Break will be lost to cover the rest of the closing days, which will be Monday, April 6th, Tuesday, April 7th and Wednesday, April 8th.

If school must be closed beyond the next two weeks, the balance of Spring Break days will be lost and the waiver will apply. More information will follow as it becomes available.
￼

post_text: Representatives from New York State United Teachers visited the Ellenville Central School District on February 28 to draw attention to the impact a lack of state funding has had on schools across the state. During a roundtable discussion between union leaders, school administrators, and mental health counselors, representatives from all parties called on state officials to make full funding of Foundation Aid a top priority this legislative session. According to Superintendent of Schools Lisa Wiles, underfunding has left the District with a lack of support for students’ social-emotional needs, as well as resources for arts and music programs.
